title: ssmodels: A package for fit the sample selection models
text: order facilitate adjustment sample selection models existing literature, created ssmodels package. package allows adjustment classic Heckman model (Heckman (1976), Heckman (1979)), estimation parameters model via maximum likelihood method two-step method, addition adjustment Heckman-t models, introduced literature Marchenko Genton (2012) Heckman-Skew model introduced literature Ogundimu Hutton (2016). also implemented functions adjust generalized version Heckman model, introduced Bastos, Barreto-Souza, Genton (2022), allows inclusion covariables dispersion correlation parameters function adjust Heckman-BS model introduced Bastos Barreto-Souza (2020) uses Birnbaum-Saunders distribution joint distribution selection primary regression variables.

title: ssmodels: A package for fit the sample selection models
text: US National Health Nutrition Examination Study (NHANES) survey data collected US National Center Health Statistics. survey data dates back 1999, individuals ages interviewed home annually complete health examination component survey. study variables include demographic variables (e.g.Â age annual household income), physical measurements (e.g.Â BMI â€“ body mass index), health variables (e.g.Â diabetes status), lifestyle variables (e.g.Â smoking status). data frame contains following columns: id: Individual identifier age: Age gender: Sex 1=male, 0=female educ: Education dichotomized high school versus less high school race: categorical variable five levels income: Household income ($1000 per year) reported range values dollar (e.g.Â 0â€“4999, 5000â€“9999, etc.) 10 interval categories. *Income: Household income ($1000 per year) reported range values dollar (e.g.Â 0â€“4999, 5000â€“9999, etc.) 10 interval categories. bmi: body mass index sbp: systolic blood pressure
code: library(ssmodels) data(nhanes) attach(nhanes) perc <- function(x,data){     nna <- ifelse(sum(is.na(x))!=0,summary(x)[[7]],0)     perc <- ifelse(sum(is.na(x))!=0,(nna/length(data$id))*100,0)    return(perc) } Variables <- c("SBP (mm Hg)", "Age (year)", "Gender", "BMI (Kg/$m^{2}$)", "Education (years)", "Race", "Income ($\\$1000$ per year)", "Numbers Obs.") perc1 <- round(perc(sbp,nhanes), digits = 2) perc2 <- round(perc(age,nhanes), digits = 2) perc3 <- round(perc(gender,nhanes), digits = 2) perc4 <- round(perc(bmi,nhanes), digits = 2) perc5 <- round(perc(educ,nhanes), digits = 2) perc6 <- round(perc(race,nhanes), digits = 2) perc7 <- round(perc(Income,nhanes), digits = 2) nObs <- length(Income) Percentage <- c(perc1, perc2, perc3, perc4, perc5, perc6, perc7, nObs) df <- subset(nhanes, !is.na(sbp)) df <- subset(df, !is.na(bmi)) attach(df) perc11 <- round(perc(sbp,df), digits = 2) perc12 <- round(perc(age,df), digits = 2) perc13 <- round(perc(gender,df), digits = 2) perc14 <- round(perc(bmi,df), digits = 2) perc15 <- round(perc(educ,df), digits = 2) perc16 <- round(perc(race,df), digits = 2) perc17 <- round(perc(Income,df), digits = 2) nObs1 <- length(Income) Percentage1 <- c(perc11, perc12, perc13, perc14, perc15, perc16, perc17, nObs1) table <- data.frame("Variables" = Variables, "Percentage of Missing"= Percentage, "Without Missing"= Percentage1) kable(table, format = "html", align = c("c", "c", "c")) library("gridExtra") barfill <- "grey" barlines <- "black" p1 <- ggplot(df, aes(Income)) + geom_histogram( breaks = seq(0, 10, 0.5), aes(y = ..density..), colour = barlines, fill = barfill)+   scale_x_continuous(name = "Income",                    breaks = seq(0, 10, 2),                    limits=c(0, 10))  p2 <- ggplot(df, aes(log(sbp))) + geom_histogram( colour = barlines, fill = barfill) +   scale_x_continuous(name = "Log Systolic blood pressure") grid.arrange(p1, p2, ncol=2) df$YS <- ifelse(is.na(df$Income),0,1) df$educ <- ifelse(df$educ<=2,0,1) df$Income <- ifelse(is.na(df$Income),0,df$Income) attach(df) selectionEq <- YS~age+gender+educ+race outcomeEq   <- log(sbp)~age+gender+educ+bmi+Income outcomeBS   <- sbp~age+gender+educ+bmi+Income mCL <- HeckmanCL(selectionEq, outcomeEq, data = df) mBS <- HeckmanBS(selectionEq, outcomeBS, data = df) mSK <- HeckmanSK(selectionEq, outcomeEq, data = df, lambda = 0) mtS <- HeckmantS(selectionEq, outcomeEq, data = df, df = 15)      Parameters <- c("Intercept", "age", "gender", "educ", "race", "Intercept", "age", "gender", "educ", "bmi", "income", "sigma", "rho", "nu", "lambda") HBS <- round(mBS$coefficients, digits = 5) HCL <- round(mCL$coefficients, digits = 5) HSK <- round(mSK$coefficients, digits = 5) HtS <- round(mtS$coefficients, digits = 5) Results <- data.frame("Parameters"= Parameters,                        "HeckmanCL" = c(HCL[1:13], "NA", "NA"),                       "HeckmanBS" = c(HBS[1:13], "NA", "NA"),                        "HeckmantS" = c(HtS[1:13], HtS[14], "NA"),                       "HeckmanSK" = c(HSK[1:13], "NA", HSK[14])) kable(Results, format = "html", align = c("c", "c", "c", "c", "c")) summary(mCL) ##  ## -------------------------------------------------------------- ##           Classic Heckman Model (Package: ssmodels)            ## -------------------------------------------------------------- ## -------------------------------------------------------------- ## Maximum Likelihood estimation  ## optim function with method BFGS - iterations number: 72  ## Log-Likelihood: -216.546  ## AIC: 459.0919 BIC: 546.5972  ## Number of observations: ( 1575 censored and 4618 observed )  ## 13 free parameters ( df = 6180 )  ## -------------------------------------------------------------- ## Probit selection equation: ##               Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     ## (Intercept)  0.4400250  0.0751788   5.853 5.07e-09 *** ## age          0.0111344  0.0008816  12.630  < 2e-16 *** ## gender       0.1362320  0.0344494   3.955 7.75e-05 *** ## educ        -0.5359430  0.0384988 -13.921  < 2e-16 *** ## race        -0.0701079  0.0134076  -5.229 1.76e-07 *** ## -------------------------------------------------------------- ## Outcome equation: ##               Estimate Std. title: Two-Step Method for Parameter Estimation of the Classical Heckman Model â€” HCinitial
Two-Step Method for Parameter Estimation of the Classical Heckman Model â€” HCinitial
text: selection formula specifying selection equation. outcome formula specifying outcome equation. data data frame containing variables model.

title: Two-Step Method for Parameter Estimation of the Classical Heckman Model â€” HCinitial
text: named numeric vector containing: Coefficients selection equation (probit model), Coefficients outcome equation (excluding IMR), Estimated sigma, Estimated rho.

title: Two-Step Method for Parameter Estimation of the Classical Heckman Model â€” HCinitial
text: function implements two-step approach proposed Heckman (1979) estimate parameters classic sample selection model. particularly useful obtaining initial values maximum likelihood estimation (MLE). first step, probit model fitted selection equation estimate probability selection. second step involves estimating linear regression outcome equation observed (selected) data, incorporating inverse Mills ratio (IMR) additional regressor correct sample selection bias. function also estimates: sigma: standard deviation outcome equation's error term. rho: correlation coefficient errors selection outcome equations.

title: Two-Step Method for Parameter Estimation of the Classical Heckman Model â€” HCinitial
text: James J Heckman (1979). â€œSample selection bias specification error.â€ Econometrica: Journal econometric society, 153â€“161.

title: Two-Step Method for Parameter Estimation of the Classical Heckman Model â€” HCinitial
code: data(MEPS2001) attach(MEPS2001) selectEq <- dambexp ~ age + female + educ + blhisp + totchr + ins + income outcomeEq <- lnambx ~ age + female + educ + blhisp + totchr + ins HCinitial(selectEq, outcomeEq, data = MEPS2001) #> xs(Intercept)         xsage      xsfemale        xseduc      xsblhisp  #>  -0.668643899   0.086814848   0.663505390   0.061883892  -0.365784312  #>      xstotchr         xsins      xsincome xo(Intercept)         xoage  #>   0.795747277   0.169106526   0.002677301   5.288927373   0.202466773  #>      xofemale        xoeduc      xoblhisp      xototchr         xoins  #>   0.292133967   0.012388871  -0.182865733   0.500633176  -0.046509658  #>         sigma           rho  #>   1.290541875  -0.359316986

what: Heckman-BS Model Fit Function â€” HeckmanBS
title: Heckman-BS Model Fit Function â€” HeckmanBS
text: Fits Heckman Sample Selection Model based Birnbaum-Saunders (BS) bivariate distribution. function implements maximum likelihood estimation model parameters.

title: Heckman-BS Model Fit Function â€” HeckmanBS
code: HeckmanBS(selection, outcome, data = sys.frame(sys.parent()), start = NULL)

title: Heckman-BS Model Fit Function â€” HeckmanBS
text: selection formula object specifying selection equation. outcome formula object specifying primary outcome equation. data data frame containing variables model. start optional numeric vector initial parameter values. provided, default values used.

title: Heckman-BS Model Fit Function â€” HeckmanBS
text: list containing: coefficients: named numeric vector estimated model parameters. value: value likelihood function optimum. loglik: (negative) maximum log-likelihood. counts: Number gradient evaluations performed. hessian: Hessian matrix optimum. fisher_infoBS: (approximate) Fisher information matrix. prop_sigmaBS: Approximate standard errors (square root Fisher information diagonal). level: Levels selection variable. nObs: Number observations dataset. nParam: Number parameters estimated. N0: Number observations selection variable zero. N1: Number observations selection variable one. NXS: Number parameters selection equation. NXO: Number parameters outcome equation. df: Degrees freedom (observations minus number parameters). aic: Akaike Information Criterion. bic: Bayesian Information Criterion. initial.value: Initial values used optimization.

title: Heckman-BS Model Fit Function â€” HeckmanBS
text: function estimates parameters Heckman-BS model, extends classical Heckman model assuming error terms follow bivariate Birnbaum-Saunders distribution. model number parameters classical Heckman model, including correlation coefficient error terms. optimization performed using optim function BFGS method. estimated quantities include: Coefficients selection equation. Coefficients outcome equation. Estimated sigma (scale parameter outcome equation's error term). Estimated rho (correlation coefficient error terms). Additional outputs include measures model fit, standard errors (approximated square root diagonal inverse Fisher information matrix), diagnostic information.

what: ssmodels: Sample Selection Models in R â€” ssmodels
title: ssmodels: Sample Selection Models in R â€” ssmodels
text: ssmodels package provides functions fit data affected sample selection bias. includes several extensions classical Heckman selection model, allowing different assumptions joint distribution selection outcome equations.

title: ssmodels: Sample Selection Models in R â€” ssmodels
text: selection Selection equation. outcome Outcome regression equation. outcomeS Covariates dispersion model (optional). outcomeC Covariates correlation model (optional). df Initial value degrees freedom (Heckman-t model). lambda Initial value skewness parameter (Heckman-SK model). start Optional vector starting values optimization. data Data frame containing relevant variables.

title: ssmodels: Sample Selection Models in R â€” ssmodels
text: list estimated parameters, diagnostics (AIC, BIC, log-likelihood), standard errors, relevant information.

title: ssmodels: Sample Selection Models in R â€” ssmodels
text: following models implemented: HeckmanCL Classic Heckman model (Tobit-2). HeckmantS Heckman model Student's t-distribution. HeckmanSK Heckman model Skew-Normal distribution. HeckmanBS Heckman model Birnbaum-Saunders distribution. HeckmanGe Generalized Heckman model covariates dispersion   correlation structures. package also includes helper functions computing Inverse Mills Ratios (IMR), post-processing parameter vectors, two-step initial value estimation.

title: ssmodels: Sample Selection Models in R â€” ssmodels
text: James J Heckman (1979). â€œSample selection bias specification error.â€ Econometrica: Journal econometric society, 153â€“161.

title: ssmodels: Sample Selection Models in R â€” ssmodels

title: Heckman's Two-Step Method â€” step2
text: Estimates parameters classical Heckman selection model using two-step method. first step fits probit model selection equation. second step, inverse Mills ratio (IMR) included additional regressor outcome equation.

title: Heckman's Two-Step Method â€” step2
Heckman's Two-Step Method â€” step2
text: YS binary vector indicating selection (1 observed, 0 otherwise). XS matrix covariates selection equation. YO numeric vector representing outcome variable interest. XO matrix covariates outcome equation.

title: Heckman's Two-Step Method â€” step2
text: numeric vector containing parameter estimates two-step Heckman model: Coefficients selection equation (probit model). Coefficients outcome equation (excluding IMR term). Estimated sigma. Estimated rho.

title: Heckman's Two-Step Method â€” step2
text: function implements two-step estimation procedure classical Heckman model. first step, probit model estimated predict selection indicator YS using selection covariates XS. IMR calculated model. second step, ordinary least squares (OLS) regression observed outcome YO XO IMR performed uncensored observations (YS == 1). function also calculates: sigma: estimated standard deviation outcome equation's error term. rho: estimated correlation error terms selection outcome equations.

title: Heckman's Two-Step Method â€” step2

title: ssmodels 2.0.0
text: Complete overhaul package, improving organization, readability, performance functions. Rewritten log-likelihood gradient functions (loglik_* gradlik_*) enhanced numerical stability clarity. Fixed discrepancies analytical gradients match numerical gradients. Comprehensive documentation updates functions, ensuring better understanding usage. postprocess_theta(): streamlines parameter transformations clear interpretation improved consistency across models. extract_model_components(): extracts model.frame, model.matrix, model.response objects robust reusable way. functions now follow consistent coding style best practices. Significant performance improvements, making package lighter efficient.
